name: Giza Necropolis (Pyramids & Sphinx)
address: Al Haram Street, Giza Plateau, Giza, Egypt
description: The last surviving Wonder of the Ancient World—over 4,500 years old. The Great Pyramid of Khufu was the tallest man-made structure for 3,800 years. Three main pyramids (Khufu, Khafre, Menkaure), the Great Sphinx (oldest known monumental sculpture), and ancient tombs on a desert plateau. Walking distance from your hotel.
highlights: Great Pyramid interior—claustrophobic but unforgettable
Sphinx up close (often less crowded early morning)
Panoramic viewpoint behind Menkaure pyramid
Boat Museum—4,600 year old cedar solar boat
tips: Arrive at 8am opening to beat crowds
Great Pyramid interior tickets sell out—buy early
Ignore 'guides' who approach you—they're not official
Agree camel ride price BEFORE mounting (and dismounting!)
Bring water—no shade on the plateau
bestTime: Early morning (8-10am) for fewer crowds and cooler temperatures

name: Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM)
address: Al Remaya Square, Pyramids, Giza, Egypt
description: The world's largest archaeological museum, opened 2024. Houses over 100,000 artifacts including the complete Tutankhamun collection (5,000+ items, many never displayed before). The building alone is spectacular—a billion-dollar facility at the foot of the Giza pyramids. The atrium features a 12-metre Ramses II statue. Essential for understanding what you'll see at the temples.
highlights: Tutankhamun galleries—complete tomb contents, golden mask
Grand Staircase—giant statues leading to main halls
Ramses II colossus—12m statue in the Grand Atrium
Royal Mummies Hall—pharaohs face to face
Pyramid views—spectacular backdrop from the terraces
tips: Book tickets online in advance—required
Allow 3-4 hours minimum (you could spend all day)
Tutankhamun galleries are the highlight—don't rush
Audio guide worth it for context
Afternoon/evening visit avoids peak crowds
Café and restaurants on site with pyramid views
bestTime: Late afternoon (5pm entry) for sunset pyramid views from terraces

name: Abu Simbel Temples
built: ~1264-1244 BC by Ramses II (New Kingdom, 19th Dynasty)
address: Abu Simbel, Aswan Governorate, Egypt (280km south of Aswan)
description: Two massive rock temples carved into a mountainside by Ramses II—one of Egypt's greatest pharaohs who ruled for 66 years. The Great Temple features four 20-metre colossal statues of Ramses. The smaller temple honours his wife Nefertari. Famously relocated 65 metres higher by UNESCO (1964-1968) to save them from Lake Nasser flooding—one of history's greatest archaeological rescues.
highlights: Four 20m colossal statues of Ramses II
Temple interior with 8 Osiride statues
Nefertari's smaller temple—rare equal-sized depiction of queen
Sun Festival alignment (Feb 22 & Oct 22—sun illuminates inner sanctuary)
tips: 3:30am pickup is brutal but worth it
Light hits facade perfectly around 7-8am
Bring breakfast—cafes open but limited
Photography allowed but no flash inside
Convoy returns ~1pm—rest in Aswan afternoon
bestTime: Dawn arrival (7am) when sunlight illuminates the facade

name: Philae Temple (Temple of Isis)
address: Agilkia Island, 8km south of Aswan (boat required)
description: Beautiful island temple dedicated to goddess Isis—the last place where ancient Egyptian religion was practiced (closed 550 AD). Built over 400 years by Ptolemaic and Roman rulers. Relocated stone-by-stone by UNESCO (1977-1980) from Philae Island to Agilkia Island after the Aswan High Dam threatened it. Stunning setting surrounded by the Nile. Sound & Light show available evenings ($20).
highlights: Island setting—approach by boat is magical
Birth colonnade—reliefs of Horus as child
Trajan's Kiosk (the 'Pharaoh's Bed')—iconic photo spot
Graffiti from 1800s explorers
tips: Negotiate boat price before boarding (should be ~200 EGP shared)
Allow 1.5-2 hours for visit
Sound & Light show worth it if you have time
Afternoon light best for photos
Combine with felucca ride back to Aswan
bestTime: Late afternoon for golden light on the columns

name: Kom Ombo Temple
description: Unique "double temple"—the only one in Egypt dedicated to two gods simultaneously: Sobek (crocodile god of fertility) and Haroeris (Horus the Elder, sky god). Perfectly symmetrical with two of everything—two entrances, two halls, two sanctuaries. Features ancient medical instruments carved in stone and a Nilometer for measuring floods. Adjacent crocodile museum displays 300+ mummified crocodiles.
highlights: Double symmetry—compare left (Horus) vs right (Sobek) sides
Ancient surgical instruments relief—world's oldest medical images
Crocodile Museum—300+ mummified crocs, some 4m long
Nilometer—ancient flood measurement device
tips: Crocodile museum ticket separate but worth it
45 mins is enough for temple
Temple lit beautifully at night if you can swing evening visit
Café overlooking Nile for quick refreshment
bestTime: Morning (on route to Luxor) or sunset for dramatic lighting

name: Edfu Temple (Temple of Horus)
address: West bank of Nile, Edfu (60km north of Aswan, 105km south of Luxor)
description: Best-preserved ancient temple in Egypt—buried under sand for 2,000 years, which protected it. Dedicated to Horus, the falcon god. Second largest temple after Karnak. Impressive 36-metre pylon gateway and detailed hieroglyphics throughout telling the story of Horus vs Seth.
highlights: 36m pylon entrance—one of Egypt's tallest temple gateways
Granite Horus statue—falcon god at entrance
Hypostyle hall—18 massive columns
Birth House (Mammisi)—reliefs of divine birth of Horus
Innermost sanctuary—still has the original shrine
tips: Horse carriage from dock included in most tours
Can get very hot inside—bring water
1 hour is enough, but don't rush
Look up at ceiling—original blue paint survives
Ignore persistent vendors at entrance
bestTime: Midday (least crowded as cruise ships visit morning/evening)

name: Valley of the Kings
address: West Bank, Luxor (18 miles NW of city centre)
entry: 770 EGP (~£12) for 3 tombs; +700 EGP Tutankhamun; +2000 EGP Seti I
description: Royal burial ground for 500 years where pharaohs were buried in hidden rock-cut tombs instead of pyramids (to avoid tomb robbers). Contains 63 known tombs including Tutankhamun (KV62, discovered 1922). Vivid painted walls depicting the pharaoh's journey to the afterlife. UNESCO World Heritage Site. Go early—tombs get hot and crowded.
highlights: Ramses VI (KV9)—stunning astronomical ceiling
Tutankhamun (KV62)—see the actual mummy
Seti I (KV17)—finest paintings (extra ticket)
Ramses III (KV11)—colourful, less crowded
Thutmose III (KV34)—oldest decorated tomb
tips: Arrive at 6am opening—tombs become ovens by 10am
Tut tomb is small and crowded—consider if worth extra fee
Photography BANNED in all tombs (phones confiscated)
Take the tram (5 EGP) to save energy for tombs
Choose 3 included tombs wisely—Ramses VI is best value
bestTime: 6am opening—essential for cooler temperatures and fewer crowds

name: Mortuary Temple of Hatshepsut
address: Deir el-Bahari, West Bank, Luxor (5km from city centre)
description: Dramatic three-tiered temple built into limestone cliffs for Hatshepsut—Egypt's most powerful female pharaoh who ruled as king for 20 years. Unique colonnaded design by architect Senenmut. Beautiful reliefs depicting her divine birth and trade expeditions to Punt (modern Somalia). Her stepson Thutmose III later tried to erase her from history.
highlights: Punt Colonnade—reliefs of expedition to Somalia
Hathor Chapel—cow-goddess with human face
Birth Colonnade—divine conception story
Anubis Chapel—well-preserved jackal-god reliefs
Views from top terrace—dramatic cliff backdrop
tips: Very hot in summer—little shade on approach
Tram available from entrance to temple (5 EGP)
45-60 mins is enough
Best combined with Valley of Kings same morning
Look for surviving Hatshepsut images—many were defaced
bestTime: Early morning (7-8am) for best light on the cliffs

name: Medinet Habu (Temple of Ramses III)
address: West Bank, Luxor (near Colossi of Memnon)
description: Second largest temple complex in Egypt with the best-preserved original colour on reliefs anywhere. Built by Ramses III—the last great warrior pharaoh. Vivid battle scenes depicting victories over the Sea Peoples. Often less crowded than Karnak—a hidden gem. The massive fortified gateway is unique in Egyptian architecture.
highlights: Migdol gateway—Syrian-style fortified entrance (unique in Egypt)
First Court—battle reliefs still have original paint
Second Court—feast and religious scenes
Hypostyle Hall—massive columns with vibrant colours
Palace remains—royal window of appearances
tips: Often empty—one of the most peaceful West Bank sites
Don't skip it for Karnak—colours here are better
Combine with Colossi of Memnon (5 min drive)
Photography allowed—great for colourful shots
45 mins to 1 hour recommended
bestTime: Late morning (colours pop in direct sunlight)

name: Karnak Temple
address: East Bank, 3km north of Luxor city centre
description: Largest religious complex ever built—so big you could fit 10 European cathedrals inside. Dedicated to Amun-Ra, king of the gods. The Great Hypostyle Hall contains 134 massive columns (the largest are 21m tall, 3m diameter). Built by 30 pharaohs over 2,000 years, each adding their own section. UNESCO World Heritage Site. Best visited early morning or late afternoon.
highlights: Great Hypostyle Hall—134 columns, each 3m diameter
Sacred Lake—used for ritual purification
Obelisks—Hatshepsut's 30m obelisk still stands
Scarab statue—walk around 7 times for luck
Avenue of Sphinxes—recently excavated connection to Luxor Temple
tips: Massive site—allow 2-3 hours minimum
Afternoon crowds thinner than morning
Hypostyle Hall best photographed when sun shafts stream through
Sound & Light show available (skip if tired)
Hire guide at entrance for context—worth it here
bestTime: Late afternoon (3-5pm) for shafts of light through columns

name: Luxor Temple
built: ~1400 BC by Amenhotep III, expanded by Ramses II (New Kingdom)
address: East Bank, Luxor city centre (Nile Corniche)
description: City centre temple connected to Karnak by the 3km Avenue of Sphinxes (recently restored). Originally built by Amenhotep III, massively expanded by Ramses II who added the famous entrance pylons. Stunning when floodlit at night. Features colossal Ramses II statues and one remaining obelisk (its twin stands in Place de la Concorde, Paris—a gift to France in 1833).
highlights: Night visit—dramatically floodlit after dark
Avenue of Sphinxes—recently restored 3km processional way
Colossal Ramses II statues at entrance
Abu el-Haggag Mosque—built INTO the temple
Missing obelisk spot—twin now in Paris
tips: MUST visit at night—completely different experience
Walk the Avenue of Sphinxes to/from Karnak (free)
Combine with dinner at nearby Sofra restaurant
Allow 1-1.5 hours for thorough visit
Less crowded than Karnak—good evening option
bestTime: After dark (7-9pm) when floodlights transform the temple

name: Dendera Temple (Temple of Hathor)
description: Best-preserved temple ceiling in Egypt with famous zodiac (original now in the Louvre). Dedicated to Hathor, goddess of love, music and joy. One of the last temples built in ancient Egypt. Rare rooftop access with stunning views. Fewer tourists than Luxor sites—peaceful experience. Often combined with Abydos.
highlights: Ceiling paintings—best preserved in Egypt
Zodiac relief—replica (original in Louvre)
Rooftop access—rare opportunity, stunning views
Crypts—underground chambers open to explore
Hathor columns—goddess faces carved on capitals
tips: Combine with Abydos for full day trip
Much less crowded than Luxor temples
Rooftop stairs steep but worth the climb
Crypts require flashlight (use phone)
Half day trip from Luxor (~3-4 hours on site)
bestTime: Morning departure from Luxor to avoid afternoon heat

name: Temple of Abydos & Osireion
built: ~1294-1279 BC by Seti I (New Kingdom, 19th Dynasty)
description: Sacred burial site of Osiris (god of the afterlife)—the most important pilgrimage site in ancient Egypt. Temple of Seti I has the finest reliefs in Egypt, still retaining vivid original colours. Contains the famous Abydos King List—a chronological list of 76 pharaohs. Mysterious Osireion behind temple (restricted access). Often combined with Dendera.
highlights: Abydos King List—76 pharaohs in chronological order
Seti I reliefs—finest quality carvings in Egypt
Original paint—colours preserved for 3,200 years
Seven chapels—one for each major deity
Osireion—mysterious subterranean structure (view only)
tips: Long drive (3hrs each way)—combine with Dendera
Worth it for serious Egyptian history fans
Very few tourists—almost private experience
Bring lunch—limited food options
Guide essential here—complex symbolism
bestTime: Full day trip combining with Dendera (depart 7am)

name: Nubian Village
address: West Bank, Aswan (boat from Elephantine Island)
description: Colourful traditional Nubian community with brightly painted houses in blues, yellows and oranges. The Nubian people have their own language, culture and traditions distinct from Arab Egypt. Friendly locals, henna tattoos, pet crocodiles, traditional food. Best reached by boat—scenic Nile trip. A living cultural experience, not an ancient monument.
highlights: Brightly painted houses—blues, yellows, oranges
Pet crocodiles—baby crocs to hold (tip expected)
Henna tattoos—traditional Nubian designs
Traditional Nubian food—try fatta or molokhia
Nubian music—often live in evening
tips: Book boat through hotel or Kana Kato
Afternoon best—houses look stunning in golden light
Bring small notes for tips (10-20 EGP)
Don't feel pressured to buy souvenirs
Combine with felucca ride back to Elephantine
bestTime: Late afternoon for best colours on painted houses
